Article.ArticleTitle: Stable O<sub>3</sub> Decomposition by Layered Double Hydroxides: The Pivotal Role of NiOOH Transformation.

AbstractText: Because ozone (O<sub>3</sub>) is a significant air pollutant, advanced O<sub>3</sub> elimination technologies, particularly those under high-humidity conditions, have become an essential research focus. In this study, a nickel-iron layered double hydroxide (NiFe-LDH) was modified via intercalation with octanoate to develop an effective hydrophobic catalyst (NiFe-OAa-LDH) for O<sub>3</sub> decomposition. The NiFe-OAa-LDH catalyst sustained its O<sub>3</sub> decomposition rate of >98% for 48 h under conditions of 90% relative humidity, 840 L/(g·h) space velocity, and 100 ppm inlet O<sub>3</sub> concentration. Moreover, it maintained a decomposition rate of 90% even when tested at a higher airflow rate of 2500 L/(g·h). Based on the changes induced by the Ni-O<sup>II</sup> to Ni-O<sup>III</sup> bonds in NiFe-OAa-LDH during O<sub>3</sub> treatment, catalytic O<sub>3</sub> decomposition was proposed to occur in two stages. The first stage involved the reaction between the hydroxyl groups and O<sub>3</sub>, leading to the breakage of the O-H bonds, formation of NiOOH, and structural changes in the catalyst. This transformation resulted in the formation of abundant and stable hydrogen vacancies. According to density functional theory calculations, O<sub>3</sub> can be effectively decomposed at the hydrogen vacancies with a low energy barrier during the second stage. This study provides new insights into O<sub>3</sub> decomposition.
